Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t)\\) defined over time, where the state of \\(z(t)\\) at any time t is influenced by \\(z_0\\) and a transformation \\(z(t) = e^{iAt}z_0\\), with \\(A\\) a real constant. We investigate the role of applying a linear transformation \\(f(z) = Bz\\), where \\(B\\) is another constant matrix.

Upon observing the resultant \\(z(T)\\), can it be concluded whether the initial vector was \\(z_0\\) or \\(Bz_0\\) without knowing if the transformation \\(f(z)\\) was applied at the outset?
Explanation: Since the function \\(f(z) = Bz\\) could alter the state in a non-identifiable way (if the matrix B commutes with \\(e^{iAt}\\)), it is not possible to unequivocally backtrack to the exact initial conditions just by knowing \\(z(T)\\), without clear information on whether the transformation was applied.
